p: Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infectious disease. Although the geographical origin of dengue is still under some debate, the recent global expansion has been attributed to environmental changes, unprecedented population growth, uncontrolled urbanization, spread of the mosquito vectors, and host population movements [ 1]. Currently, dengue is endemic in more than 100 countries in much of the globe’s tropical and subtropical areas, being reported predominantly in Southeast Asia, the Americas, and the Western Pacific, and less frequently in Africa and Eastern Mediterranean WHO regions [ 2]. The prevalence of dengue has increased 74.7% between 2006 and 2016 [ 3]. While dengue infections are most often asymptomatic, a recent study has estimated a global total of 58.4 (95% CI: 24–122) million symptomatic dengue cases occur annually costing some US$8.9 (95% CI: 3.7–19.7) billion [ 4].
